title: The Kind of Fasting God Rejects
description: As we approach Great Lent, Father Josiah Trenham reflects on what it truly means to fast in a way that pleases God. Drawing from the Gospel parable of the Publican and the Pharisee and the teaching of the Prophet Isaiah, this talk explains why fasting without humility and repentance is empty, and how true fasting deepens prayer, heals the heart, and renews our spiritual life. 00:00 Preparing for Great Lent 02:05 The Fast That Condemns Instead of Heals 04:33 Fasting Without Repentance Is Empty 05:00 Isaiah 58 and Gods Rebuke 08:36 What True Fasting Looks Like Download the *Patristic Nectar App* everywhere! title: Blasphemy Laws
description: In this reflection, Father Josiah Trenham explores whether blasphemy laws are truly un-American. Drawing from Christian history, early American legal tradition, and constitutional reasoning, he argues that reverence for Gods name was once understood as foundational to civic peace and moral order. This talk examines the relationship between faith, freedom of speech, and the moral health of a nation. 0:00 Introduction  Are Blasphemy Laws Un-American? 1:07 Historical Christian View of Blasphemy 3:09 Blasphemy Laws in Early America 5:23 Free Speech, the Constitution, and Moral Limits 7:44 Why a Nation Cannot Flourish While Mocking God 10:00 Final Exhortation and Call to Reverence Download the *Patristic Nectar App* everywhere! title: AI Erotica
description: Father Josiah gives a reflection on the rise of AI-generated erotica and the spiritual catastrophe of pornography in the digital age. Father also exposes how tech giants are fueling addiction, destroying relationships, and enslaving souls  and calls us to purity, discipline, and custody of the eyes. Prayer against Internet Pornography  Before turning on the computer, make three bows, kiss the holy icons, and say: *O Lord Jesus Christ, my God and Savior, through the prayers of Thy Most Pure Mother and of my Patron Saint and Guardian Angel, preserve me from all sinful pleasures in all my senses; help me not to look at evil and impure images that will harm my soul and separate me from Thee; help me to cut off the desire to indulge in such unchaste activity; and help me rather to do work that is productive and pleasing to Thee and to Thy Church, that I may glorify Thee, together with Thine Unoriginate Father and the Most Holy, Good and Life-creating Spirit, now and ever and unto the ages of ages. description: In this reflection, Father Josiah draws from Scripture and Church tradition to speak candidly about the reality of rotten priests. title: The Revolutionary Manifesto of Jesus
description: In this reflection, Fr. Josiah Trenham offers a profound meditation on the opening of the Sermon on the Mountknown as the Beatitudeswhich he calls Christs Revolutionary Manifesto. title: What Makes Jesuss Baptism So Much Greater?
description: Whats the real difference between John the Baptists baptism and the baptism of Jesus Christ? In this powerful Orthodox reflection, Fr. Josiah Trenham explains why Johns baptismthough it forgave sinswas only a partial prelude to the life-giving, Spirit-filled baptism offered by Christ. Drawing on Holy Scripture, the Church Fathers (especially St. Photius the Great), and deep Orthodox theology, Fr. Josiah shows why Christian baptism is more than waterit's fire, Spirit, renewal, and adoption into the family of God. title: Prophet Elias: A Type of Christ
description: In this powerful reflection, Father Josiah Trenham explores how the Holy Prophet Elias (Elijah) prefigures our Lord Jesus Christ. From miraculous acts, fierce asceticism, and fiery confrontations with idolatry, to his heavenly ascension, Elias stands as a vivid type of Christ in the Old Testament. Discover how Elias's life foreshadows the Incarnation, the miracles of Christ, and the coming of the Holy Spirit. Released in honor of the Prophets feast day, July 20th, this message will inspire renewed devotion to Christ and gratitude for His saints. title: The Double Gaze
description: This Pentecost reflection, titled The Double Gaze, explores the profound moment of Christ's Ascensionhow Jesus, while blessing the disciples, fixed his loving gaze on them as He rose to the right hand of God. title: Ending Atheistic Education
description: In this reflection, Father Josiah Trenham responds to a recent Supreme Court ruling involving a Catholic charter school in Oklahoma. He uses the case to highlight deeper concerns about the lack of school choice, the forced public funding of anti-Christian education, and the overall decline of moral and academic standards in the U.S. education system.Why are families restricted from directing their tax dollars to schools that reflect their values? What are the long-term effects of an aggressively secular public school system? Is there hope for restoring freedom and faith in American education? Father Josiah calls for renewed moral clarity, Christian engagement, and educational liberty in a time of deep cultural confusion. title: What Fallen Nature Really Means
description: Father Josiah Trenham + Bishop Irenei What does it really mean to say that humanity has a fallen nature? Is this just Western theological baggage  or is it deeply rooted in Orthodox tradition? In this video, we explore how the Orthodox Church understands the language of the Fall  not as a doctrine of total depravity, but as a profound spiritual condition described throughout the Fathers, liturgical texts, and scripture. Discover why Orthodox theology still uses terms like "fallen man," and how fasting, almsgiving, and true repentance are tools for healing, not punishment. title: Christian Fugitives - St. Augustine on the Prodigal Son
description: Father Josiah Trenham Register for *The Sacred Arts Conference* featuring speakers *Jonathan Pageau* and *Fr. Maximos Constas* , taking place from March 29-31, 2024. Secure your spot at www.conference.patristicnectar.org for more details. *TEXT PNP to 53-555 to make a tax deductible donation and support our ministry. Arena Podcast (on Spotify, Apple Podcasts, and more) - https://open.spotify.com/show/1VKxdB2ZCzk8evUA4V7tku *Buy "Enduring Love: Laying Christian Foundations for Marriage" HERE:* - *Amazon:* https://www.amazon.com/Enduring-Love-Christian-Foundations-Marriage/dp/1735011657 - *Barnes & Noble:* https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/enduring-love-josiah-trenham/1144547044?ean=9781735011653# Merch Link: https://patristic-nectar.mybigcommerce.com/ Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids *Are you getting married, already married, or want to be married one day? Patristic Nectar Publications is pleased to present, "Enduring Love: Laying the Christian Foundations for Marriage" by Fr. Josiah Trenham. A new resource for engaged couples, married couples, singles hoping to wed, and priests preparing them. Be edified by 10 chapters on various topics, discussion questions, scenarios, and write notes in this workbook along with your future or current spouse. Purchase the paperback workbook at your favorite bookseller. (Amazon, Barnes & Noble, etc) Foreword by Bishop Basil (Essey) Chapter 1 - God's Design for Marriage Chapter 2 - Love and Expectations Chapter 3 - Friendship and Goals Chapter 4 - Communication and Conflict Chapter 5 - Sex and Romance Chapter 6 - Children and Parenting Chapter 7 - Roles and Responsibilities Chapter 8 - Finances Chapter 9 - Spiritual Life Chapter 10 - Enduring to the End Appendix - The Orthodox Rite of Marriage - ISBN# 978-1735011653 *Our Newest Lecture Series:* The Holy Trinity by Fr. Thomas Hopko Listen to FOR *FREE* here: https://patristicnectar.org/bookstore_220620_1122222111222 LECTURE TITLES Lecture #1 - Jesus and the One God. Lecture #2 - How Does Jesus Relate to God? Lecture #3 - Who Do People Say That I Am? (Part 1) Lecture #4 - Who Do People Say That I Am? (Part 2) Lecture #5 - Understanding Our Being in Regards to the Holy Trinity. Lecture #6 - The Trinity and the Filioque. Lecture #7 - Human Life in Imitation of God. Lecture #8 - Recapitulation. Lecture #9 - Living the Divine Life in This World. Lecture #10 - If You Want to Be Saved. Lecture #11 - Iconography Regarding the Trinity. These lectures were delivered in February of 2001 to the clergy of the Western Region (eventually the Diocese of Los Angeles and the West) of the Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese of North America. In these lectures Father Hopko opens to all the dogmatic teaching of the Orthodox Church on One God, His Only-Begotten Son our Lord Jesus Christ, and the Holy Spirit. Here Fr. Thomas shares how Christian life is a sharing in the Divine Life itself, and much more. If you are interested in other available titles, or if you would like more information on Patristic Nectar Publications, please visit our website at www.PatristicNectar.org SOCIAL MEDIA Patristic Nectar Instagram: https://bit.ly/3kmupqE Patristic Nectar Facebook: https://bit.ly/33Bzmpx Patristic Nectar Twitter: https://bit.ly/3igrH4f SUPPORT PATRISTIC NECTAR 1) Spread the Word - tell your family and friends about Patristic Nectar. Tell a friend to "Come and see!" 2) Make a Donation -Patristic Nectar is a small non-profit ministry with a big vision for expanding access to Patristic Orthodox teaching throughout the world. title: God's Kindness and Severity
description: Father Josiah Trenham Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids TEXT PNP to 53-555 to Donate Today! Our Newest Lecture Series: Demonology: Understanding & Winning the Spiritual Battle Click Here: https://patristicnectar.org/bookstore_220620_11222221112 The study of the Churchs demonology is a part of basic catechism and Christian instruction. The Scriptures are replete with teaching on the dark powers. Additionally, it is impossible to appreciate the magnitude of the saving deeds of our Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ, without understanding how He, and He alone, has conquered Satan and destroyed his works. Lastly, Christians are called to fight and win in the spiritual war, and for this reason, it is essential that believers understand their enemies and their tactics. Toward this end, Father Josiah presents in these lectures in-depth studies of the Scriptures, Divine Services, and pedagogy of great saints and teachers on the subject of Satan and spiritual battle. Lecture titles include: Lecture #1 Jesus and Satan Lecture #2 Demonology in the Baptismal Rite and the Divine Liturgy Lecture #3 Gaining Mastery of Satan: The Life of St. Anthony the Great Lecture #4 How to Win the Spiritual Battle according to St. John of the Ladder Lecture #5 Engaging the Unseen Warfare: Fr. Lorenzo Scupoli and St. Nicodemos of the Holy Mountain Lecture #6 C. S. title: Reading Scripture Liturgically
description: This interview was conducted at the conclusion of the 2022 Annual Patristic Nectar Conference, held at Saint Andrew Orthodox Christian Church, in Riverside California. If you found this interview to be of interest, and would like a deeper dive into the topic, follow the link below and watch the seven lectures and Q&A sessions delivered at the conference. Click the link below : https://www.crowdcast.io/e/holyorthodoxy/register Registration includes the audio lectures delivered to your Patristic Nectar account library. or purchase the audio only lectures (video lectures not included, must register with link above): https://patristicnectar.org/bookstore_220620_1 Fr Bogdan Bucur was born in Romania. He is married to Cristina and they are the parents of Irina (21), Andrei (10), and Miruna (6). After studying at the Faculty of Orthodox Theology in Bucharest (1994-1999), Fr Bogdan left for the USA, where he earned his MA (2002) and PhD (2007) in Religious Studies at Marquette University under the direction of (now Archbishop) Alexander Golitzin. Between 2007 and 2020, he was Assistant and then Associate Professor of Theology at Duquesne University, in Pittsburgh, where he worked in the areas of Early Christian Studies and Reception History of the Bible. In 2010 he was ordained a priest in the Antiochian Orthodox Archdiocese and served as the pastor of St Anthony Orthodox Church in Butler, PA (2010-2020). Fr Bogdan is a scholar of early Christianity, with a special interest in the link between reception history of the Bible and doctrinal developments in early Christianity and the Byzantine tradition. He views it as important to study how early Christians articulated their religious identity by reworking doctrines, imagery, and practices inherited from the many currents of Second Temple Judaism. His academic interests were shaped significantly by participation in the interdisciplinary Seminar on the Jewish Roots of Christian Mysticism, and the "Theophaneia School", both led by Professor Andrei Orlov and Archbishop Dr. Alexander Golitzin at Marquette University. title: When Compassion Becomes Betrayal of Truth

title: Bishop Irenei on Sacraments Outside the Church
description: In this teaching, Bishop Irenei addresses the often-asked question: Does the Orthodox Church acknowledge sacraments outside her life? He explains that the Orthodox understanding of the sacraments (or mysteries) is rooted in the life of the Church as the Body of Christ. By definition, sacraments are acts of the Church, enacted by Christ through His Body, and therefore cannot exist apart from her. title: It's Time to Make a Choice: Publican or Pharisee
description: Bishop Irenei of London & Western Europe (ROCOR) Register for *The Sacred Arts Conference* featuring speakers *Jonathan Pageau* and *Fr. Maximos Constas* , taking place from March 29-31, 2024. Secure your spot at www.conference.patristicnectar.org for more details. *TEXT PNP to 53-555 to make a tax deductible donation and support our ministry. *Buy "Enduring Love: Laying Christian Foundations for Marriage" HERE:* - *Amazon:* https://www.amazon.com/Enduring-Love-Christian-Foundations-Marriage/dp/1735011657 - *Barnes & Noble:* https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/enduring-love-josiah-trenham/1144547044?ean=9781735011653# Merch Link: https://patristic-nectar.mybigcommerce.com/ Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids *Are you getting married, already married, or want to be married one day? Patristic Nectar Publications is pleased to present, "Enduring Love: Laying the Christian Foundations for Marriage" by Fr. Josiah Trenham. A new resource for engaged couples, married couples, singles hoping to wed, and priests preparing them. Be edified by 10 chapters on various topics, discussion questions, scenarios, and write notes in this workbook along with your future or current spouse. Purchase the paperback workbook at your favorite bookseller. (Amazon, Barnes & Noble, etc) Foreword by Bishop Basil (Essey) Chapter 1 - God's Design for Marriage Chapter 2 - Love and Expectations Chapter 3 - Friendship and Goals Chapter 4 - Communication and Conflict Chapter 5 - Sex and Romance Chapter 6 - Children and Parenting Chapter 7 - Roles and Responsibilities Chapter 8 - Finances Chapter 9 - Spiritual Life Chapter 10 - Enduring to the End Appendix - The Orthodox Rite of Marriage - ISBN# 978-1735011653 *Our Newest Lecture Series:* The Holy Trinity by Fr. Thomas Hopko Listen to FOR *FREE* here: https://patristicnectar.org/bookstore_220620_1122222111222 LECTURE TITLES Lecture #1 - Jesus and the One God. Lecture #2 - How Does Jesus Relate to God? Lecture #3 - Who Do People Say That I Am? (Part 1) Lecture #4 - Who Do People Say That I Am? (Part 2) Lecture #5 - Understanding Our Being in Regards to the Holy Trinity. Lecture #6 - The Trinity and the Filioque. Lecture #7 - Human Life in Imitation of God. Lecture #8 - Recapitulation. Lecture #9 - Living the Divine Life in This World. Lecture #10 - If You Want to Be Saved. Lecture #11 - Iconography Regarding the Trinity. These lectures were delivered in February of 2001 to the clergy of the Western Region (eventually the Diocese of Los Angeles and the West) of the Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese of North America. title: Our Christian Names
description: Bishop Irenei of London & Western Europe (ROCOR) Register for *The Sacred Arts Conference* featuring speakers *Jonathan Pageau* and *Fr. Maximos Constas* , taking place from March 29-31, 2024. Secure your spot at www.conference.patristicnectar.org for more details. *TEXT PNP to 53-555 to make a tax deductible donation and support our ministry. *Buy "Enduring Love: Laying Christian Foundations for Marriage" HERE:* - *Amazon:* https://www.amazon.com/Enduring-Love-Christian-Foundations-Marriage/dp/1735011657 - *Barnes & Noble:* https://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/enduring-love-josiah-trenham/1144547044?ean=9781735011653# Merch Link: https://patristic-nectar.mybigcommerce.com/ Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids *Are you getting married, already married, or want to be married one day? Patristic Nectar Publications is pleased to present, "Enduring Love: Laying the Christian Foundations for Marriage" by Fr. Josiah Trenham. A new resource for engaged couples, married couples, singles hoping to wed, and priests preparing them. Purchase the paperback workbook at your favorite bookseller. title: Peace
description: Bishop Irenei of London & Western Europe (ROCOR) Merch Link: https://patristic-nectar.mybigcommerce.com/ Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids TEXT PNP to 53-555 to Donate Today! Our Newest Lecture Series: The Original Church: Lectures on the Acts of the Apostles Click Here: https://patristicnectar.org/store_lectures Our Newest Lecture Series: The Original Church: Lectures on the Acts of the Apostles by Father Josiah Trenham. The Acts was written by the Holy Apostle and Evangelist Luke, as the 2nd part of his great literary masterpiece setting forth the Life of Jesus Christ in his Gospel, and then in the Acts showing forth the new Christian life made possible by the Lords great and saving deeds and the descent of the Holy Spirit. Here in these sacred pages we discover what St. Paul calls new creation in Christ. Here we discover what is the birth-right of Christians  that is the continuous miracle of church life. Lecture titles are as follows: Lecture #1 The Meaning of the Acts Lecture #2 Pentecost Lecture #3 Spiritual Life Lecture #4 Fellowship Lecture #5 Martyrdom Lecture #6 Conversion Lecture #7 Defending the Faith: The Jerusalem Council Lecture #8 The Missionary Journeys of St. Paul If you are interested in other available titles, or if you would like more information on Patristic Nectar Publications, please visit our website at www.PatristicNectar.org SOCIAL MEDIA Patristic Nectar Instagram: https://bit.ly/3kmupqE Patristic Nectar Facebook: https://bit.ly/33Bzmpx Patristic Nectar Twitter: https://bit.ly/3igrH4f SUPPORT PATRISTIC NECTAR 1) Spread the Word - tell your family and friends about Patristic Nectar. title: Intellectualism and Martyrdom
description: Bishop Irenei of London & Western Europe (ROCOR) Merch Link: https://patristic-nectar.mybigcommerce.com/ Patristic Nectar Kids : https://www.youtube.com/@PatristicNectarKids TEXT PNP to 53-555 to Donate Today! Our Newest Lecture Series: Demonology: Understanding & Winning the Spiritual Battle Click Here: https://patristicnectar.org/bookstore_220620_11222221112 The study of the Churchs demonology is a part of basic catechism and Christian instruction. The Scriptures are replete with teachings about the dark powers. Additionally, it is impossible to appreciate the magnitude of the saving deeds of our Savior, the Lord Jesus Christ, without understanding how He, and He alone, has conquered Satan and destroyed his works. Lastly, Christians are called to fight and win in the spiritual war, and for this reason, it is essential that believers understand their enemies and their tactics. Toward this end, Father Josiah presents in these lectures in-depth studies of the Scriptures, Divine Services, and pedagogy of great saints and teachers on the subject of Satan and spiritual battle. Lecture titles include: Lecture #1 Jesus and Satan Lecture #2 Demonology in the Baptismal Rite and the Divine Liturgy Lecture #3 Gaining Mastery of Satan: The Life of St. Anthony the Great Lecture #4 How to Win the Spiritual Battle according to St. John of the Ladder Lecture #5 Engaging the Unseen Warfare: Fr. Lorenzo Scupoli and St. Nicodemos of the Holy Mountain Lecture #6 C. S. Lewis Screwtape Letters and Demonic Warfare in the 21st Century Falling West If you are interested in other available titles, or if you would like more information on Patristic Nectar Publications, please visit our website at www.PatristicNectar.org SOCIAL MEDIA Patristic Nectar Instagram: https://bit.ly/3kmupqE Patristic Nectar Facebook: https://bit.ly/33Bzmpx Patristic Nectar Twitter: https://bit.ly/3igrH4f SUPPORT PATRISTIC NECTAR 1) Spread the Word - tell your family and friends about Patristic Nectar. title: Heavenward: God Has Sent the Perfect People for You
description: Heavenward: A Womens Podcast is a new offering from Patristic Nectar Family rooted in Orthodox Christian faith and values. In this episode, Presbytera Catherine is again joined by her adult daughters, Victoria and Anastasia, for an intergenerational conversation on faith, womanhood, family, and the Christian life. Together, they share Orthodox Christian wisdom, lived experience, and thoughtful reflections for women of all ages. Whether you are a daughter, mother, sister, godmother, auntie, or grandmother, Heavenward offers meaningful conversation, encouragement, and Christ-centered perspective. Subscribe to Patristic Nectar Family for more Orthodox Christian podcasts, discussions, and family-focused content. #orthodoxchristianity #patristicnectar #patristicnectarpublications #patristicnectarfamily #biblestoriesforchildren #orthodoxwomencontent #orthodoxwomen

title: Celebrating Orthodox Name Days
description: Celebrating Name days in our Orthodox Home What is a name day? How do we celebrate name days in our Orthodox home? Exploring these questions along with some other resources you might be interested in adding to your collection! Prayer to your patron saint: Pray to God for me, O Saint name well-pleasing to God. For I turn to them who are the speedy helper and intercessor for my soul. title: House of Bread - Kid's Homily
description: Father Joseph Thornburg Welcome to our special YouTube Kids edition of Father Joseph's Sunday Gospel Homily! In this video, Father will take your little ones on a spiritual journey, simplifying the Sunday gospel readings so that kids can better understand the Sunday Liturgy.  What to Expect: A warm and friendly introduction by Father Joseph. A simplified explanation of the Sunday gospel reading, making it relatable and engaging for kids. Thought-provoking questions to spark discussion and reflection. Inspiring messages to encourage your children's faith and love for Jesus. This video is perfect for children of all ages, whether they're new to the faith or have grown up in the Orthodox tradition. It's a wonderful way to introduce them to the beauty of the gospel and its teachings. title: St Martin's Day Lantern Procession
description: The lantern procession tradition on St. Martin's Day, celebrated on November 12, is a cherished tradition honoring St. Martin of Tours (397 AD). In Germany, children make lanterns and parade through the streets, singing songs. The lanterns shining in the dark are often interpreted as symbolizing the light of Christ, a particularly appropriate image for the beginning of the Nativity Fast (November 15th). St Martin is a beloved Saint celebrated throughout the world and is known for his merciful compassion on the needy. St. Martin's Day is celebrated on November 12th in the Eastern Orthodox Church. To learn more about St Martins day, check out my blogpost at: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/martindayprocession St Martin book: Snow on Martinmas https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06WGPJGG4?ref=cm_sw_r_ffobk_cso_cp_mwn_dp_BP054EZZ3K903GGHGW18&ref_=cm_sw_r_ffobk_cso_cp_mwn_dp_BP054EZZ3K903GGHGW18&social_share=cm_sw_r_ffobk_cso_cp_mwn_dp_BP054EZZ3K903GGHGW18&bestFormat=true Be sure to download the Patristic Nectar App to listen to the daily synaxarion for the lives of the saints! title: Our Favorite Orthodox Family Habit - and Why We Love the PNP App!
description: Let's explore this simple daily habit (and some easy ways to incorporate it into your home) of reading the lives of the saints to our children. Let's explore why we should create this habit and answering some FAQs such as "are my kids too young?" Further more! When we gather as a family to read the lives of the saints, were doing something far more than simply telling stories. Reading the saints daily keeps our faith alive in the home. It reminds us that holiness isnt something distant or impossible  its what were ALL called to. And when our children grow up hearing these stories day after day, they begin to see the world differently. They learn that suffering is a participation in Christs suffers, that love is stronger than fear, and that every ordinary moment can be filled with Christ. This daily habit becomes like the lighting of a small lamp  one that keeps burning in the heart of your family. Through the witness of the saints, our homes are filled with the sweet smelling fragrance of faith, and our children come to know that they too are called to be part of this great story  the story of Christ lived out in His saints. Be sure to download the Patristic Nectar App to listen to the daily synaxarion for the lives of the saints! title: How Orthodox Christians Pray and Eat at the Table - with Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: Eating as a family with small children takes intention, patience, persistence, and tender love and care. Although I grew up eating as a family, its becoming less and less common. As a mother with 4 small children, I can understand why. Its hard work! But the seeds that are planted in their hearts through your patience and persistence will bear good fruit. My oldest is only 9 and I am already seeing the fruit of our labors. Here are some tips we have picked up along the way: ~ Assign jobs for both setting the table and clearing the table - I have found that keeping these same jobs for 1-2 months helps build confidence and allows the children to take ownership of them. All I have to say now is Do you job and they already know what to do! It makes meal times much smoother. ~ Sing and pray before each meal! This is the glue for every meal and a way of inviting christ into our homes. We are asking for Gods blessing while also expressing our gratitude! ~ Wait for everyone to be done eating, and ask to be excused - Being polite is always good, and instilling these manners is ideal at meal times. ~ Everyone brings their plate to the counter to be washed - This helps everyone! We are both being responsible for our own messes, but we are also assisting in the work. This can be done as early as 18 months old! I start my kids very young in sharing the load. They find so much satisfaction in this work! What would you add to the list? Resources: Pray Always Desk Flip Book (pictured in the video) - https://www.drawneardesigns.com/home/pray-always-desk-flip-book Rich Men have turned poor and hungry song - https://youtu.be/4W651KmSfZQ Find us on Instagram: @Asceticlifeofmotherhood and @PatristicNectarKids If you want to see more PNP Kids Content, please consider making a donation! title: St Euphrosynos the Cook Saint - baked apples recipe with Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: St Euphrosynos feast day is September 11th! You can find this September monthly printable at www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/store/septhrudec Baked Apples of Paradise for the feast of St Euphrosynos! 3 TBSP unsalted butter, softened 1/4 C packed brown sugar 1/2 tsp cinnamon 1/8 tsp nutmeg 1/4 C old-fashioned rolled oats 3 large apples 1. Preheat oven to 375F 2. Mash the butter, sugar, cinnamon, and nutmeg together until combined. Stir in the oats. 3. Core the apple with a sharp knife of apple corer about 3/4 down and scoop out a little and be sure the seeds are removed. 4. Place cored apples in a pie dish. Spoon filling into each apple, filling all the way to the top. Pour warm water into the dish around the apples. Bake for 40-45 minutes or until apples appear slightly soft. Serve warm with ice cream!

title: Day in the Life of our Orthodox Homeschool with Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: Welcome to our little corner of Orthodox homeschoolingwhere our days begin with prayer, unfold at a slow and thoughtful pace, and follow the life-giving rhythms of the Church. Here, we celebrate feast days with joy, read aloud from living books, and seek to surround ourselves with all that is good, beautiful, and true. Our family life is about connectionworking together, praying together, and growing together in Christ. Every lesson, every story, every rhythm of our day is about building a strong foundation in Him, so that when our children go out into the world, they go rooted in their true identity: their life in Christ. You can find more resources on my blog about how we follow the Liturgical cycle in our home at Asceticlifeofmotherhood.com My children are 9, 6, 4 and 2, so here are our curriculum choices this year: - Bible: Childrens Bible Reader -Childrens Synaxarion: Potamitis Publishing (My Synaxarion: August) - Christian education - @asceticlifeofmotherhood (still in the works to complete for sharing) - Nature Study (Science) - @treehouse_schoolhouse - Geography/Cultural Studied - Beautiful Feet Around the World Part 1 - Math - @thegoodandthebeautiful - Language Arts - @thegoodandthebeautiful - Reading - Teach your child to read in 100 easy lessons - Art - St Raphael Schole (Online) - Introduction to Iconography - History - state history co op taught by a dear friend

title: St Herman of Alaska Cookies
description: St. Hermans Rustic Honey Cookies Recipe (Simple, nourishing, humble) Ingredients 1 cup whole grain flour (rye or barley was more common than wheat) 1/4 cup oats 23 tbsp honey 2 tbsp coconut oil (traditionally would have been seal or bear oil) Pinch of salt Small handful of dried berries (like cranberries or blueberries), if available Water to bind (24 tbsp) Instructions Preheat oven to 350F Mix flour, oats, salt, and dried berries. Add honey and coconut oil, mixing with a spoon or fingers. Add a little water at a time until a dough forms. Shape into small, flat discs. Bake 350F for 1520 min until bottom is golden brown. Enjoy warm!  Icon used in video: Uncut Mountain Supply  Childrens Book: 101 Orthodox Saints by Ancient Faith Publishing  Sacred Alaska Film: sacredalaskafilm.com  Wooden Icon: https://sthermanstudios.com/  St Innocent Orphanage (Project Mexico) https://www.projectmexico.org

title: Blessing of Grapes for Holy Transfiguration
description: On August 6th, we celebrate the glorious Feast of the Transfiguration of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. This is one of the 12 Great Feasts in the Orthodox Church. In the Orthodox Church, it is customary to bring grapes and other first fruits to church on this day to be blessed and distributed to the faithful. Why grapes? Grapes were traditionally among the earliest fruits of the summer harvest. Offering them to God is a way of giving thanks for His provisionof saying, We receive all good things from You, and we return them with gratitude. But grapes carry even deeper spiritual meaning for us. Grapes, when pressed, become wine. And wine, offered on the altar, becomes the Blood of Christ. So these humble fruits become a powerful symbolnot just of thanksgiving, but of transformation. Just as grapes are changed, we too are called to be changedto be transfigured, to become partakers in the divine life. After the blessing, we take these grapes homeand there are so many simple and meaningful ways to use them.  Share them: Offer a small plate to a friend or neighbor. Just like the loaves and fishes, the blessed fruits of the Church are meant to be shared.  Make a simple lenten-friendly charcuterie board with fruits, olives, nuts, and bread. Since the feast falls during the Dormition Fast, its a beautiful way to honor the day while keeping the fast.  Include children: Let little ones help wash the grapes, arrange them, and light a candle as you read the Gospel story of the Transfiguration together.  Feast with joy: This is a fast day, but the Church gives us a joyful exception: were allowed wine, oil, and even fish on this feast. Its a day of light and gladness, and the Church invites us to celebrate. Blessed feast! Please, Like and Subscribe to our channel at Patristic Nectar Kids! title: Living Liturgically: Following the Orthodox Church Calendar
description: Feeling overwhelmed by the Church calendar? Youre not alone. Liturgical living can feel like trying to drink from a firehose especially when youre new to Orthodoxy. But what if we slowed down and embraced it one step at a time?  In this video, Im sharing how weve begun weaving the rhythm of the Church into our home lifeand how you can too, without burnout or guilt. Heres a peek at one of our new family traditions:  A simple, meaningful feast day meal for St. Marinacomplete with  Super Fast Dragon Noodles (yes, really!)  As we ate, we read her life and talked about how she crushed the devil (aka the dragon) with the power of the Cross.  Scroll down for the recipe + some encouragement on sustainable liturgical living. Lets bring the Church home, one beautiful day at a time.  Super Fast Dragon Noodles for the feast of St Marina 1 Package of Squiggly Knife cut noodles from Trader Joes 1 Package of stir fry vegetables 1 Tbsp olive oil 1 Tbsp brown sugar 1 garlic clove (crushed) or 1 tsp garlic powder 1 tsp crushed ginger or 1 tsp ginger powder Top of sesame seeds or green onions Cook noodles according to package directions. In a bowl, mix the provided sauce packets, along with 1 TBSP brown sugar, 1 crushed garlic clove, and 1 tsp ginger. Mix well. Saute vegetables in 1 tbsp oil, until soft and slightly browned. Add cooked noodles to the sauted vegetables and add sauce to the top. With low heat, mix the vegetables, noodles, and sauce until well incorporated. Serve immediately and add sesame seeds and green onions to garnish. This recipe came together in 10 mins, and as we ate, we read the life of St Marina, and discussed how she overcame the temptations of the devil (traditionally portrayed as a dragon) and defeated him with the cross. title: Sweet-Scented Playdough for St. Joanna
description: Celebrate the feast of St. Joanna, one of the Myrrhbearing Women, with this easy homemade playdough craft!  As you mix and knead, talk with your kids about the sweet smell of holiness and the beautiful gifts the Myrrhbearers brought to Christs tomb.   Ingredients:  1 cup flour  1/4 cup salt  1 tbsp cream of tartar  1 tbsp vegetable oil  3/4 cup boiling water  Natural food coloring (optional)  A few drops of essential oils (lavender, frankincense, rose, etc.)  Instructions: 1 Mix dry ingredients in a bowl 2 Add oil + boiling water 3 Stir until combined, then knead 4 Add essential oils + knead again  Perfect for little hands and big conversations about faith  #StJoanna #MyrrhbearingWomen #OrthodoxKids #FaithAndCrafts #PlaydoughRecipe #LiturgicalLiving #OrthodoxMoms #HomemadePlaydough #SweetSmellOfHoliness

title: Sunday of the Blind Man
description: Father Joseph Thornburg Join us for a joyful and simple homily for children on the Sunday of the Blind Man! In this Gospel story, Jesus heals a man born blindand shows us how He brings light to our hearts too. Kids will learn how to see with faith, trust Jesus, and understand His love through this powerful miracle. Perfect for Orthodox families and Sunday school! Welcome to our special YouTube Kids edition of Father Jason's Sunday Gospel Homily! title: Painting Water Jars for the Sunday of the Samaritan Woman
description: Christ is risen! This Sunday we commemorate the Samaritan woman, or the Women at the Well, known to us as St Photini. To remember this beautiful encounter, were going to do a simple and meaningful craft. Well paint flowers on a glass water jara symbol of the living water Jesus spoke about.  Heres what youll need: A clean glass jar, pitcher, or holy water jar Acrylic paint or paint pens Paint brushes Mod podge Choose Light, joyful colorsblues, whites, pinks, even gold. You can paint flowers, vines, or even drops of water - symbols of life! You can paint directly onto the jar. As you paint, think about what living water means to you. What has Jesus healed or renewed in your own life? After your painting is dry, you can paint a layer of mod podge over it to make it waterproof. This jar or pitcher will be a reminder in your home of the transformed life of St Photini and the living waters that Christ offers each of us. If you paint a jar, tag Patristic Nectar Kids so we can share your beautiful creations! To learn more, check out our video with Fr Jason on the Samaritan Woman (https://youtu.be/W5NogJXs3Gk?feature=shared) Find us on Instagram: @Asceticlifeofmotherhood and @PatristicNectarKids If you want to see more PNP Kids Content, please consider making a donation! title: Artist's Corner | Saint Mary of Egypt
description: Join us at our Artist's Corner for guided art projects with stories of great saints! Listen to the life of St Mary of Egypt and draw a lion with our artist in today's video. April 1st is the Nameday of St Mary of Egypt. The Wednesday before the Fifth Sunday of Lent is marked by special prayers and hymns that highlight Saint Mary of Egypt's repentance and ascetic struggles. This midweek observance helps believers reflect on her steadfast commitment to God and prepares them to fully engage with her commemoration on Sunday. Saint Marys life teaches that transformation is possible through humility and reliance on God. Her commemoration during Lent inspires Orthodox Christians to complete their spiritual journey with hope and courage as they approach the celebration of Pascha, the Resurrection of Christ! Saint Mary and Saint Zosimas remind us to trust in Gods forgiveness and strive for holiness. May their story inspire us to live with faith and humility. #orthodoxchristianity #patristicnectar #patristicnectarpublications #patristicnectarkids #easternorthodoxy #lent #biblestoriesforkids #biblestoriesforchildren #stmaryofegypt #drawwithme #artforkids #christianchildrencontent #chrisitanity

title: Planting a Mary Garden - Celebrating the Annunciation with Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: In Medieval times, it became popular to create Mary Gardens, gardens full of flowers and herbs that were named after the Mother of God. For the feast of the Annunciation, in honor of the day that the Theotokos (Mary) said yes to God, we planted the start of our own Mary Garden, using seeds of flowers that are named for her.  There are over 1,100 flowers that honor Mary. Here are a few that you may be familiar with, with their medieval names:  Amaryllis  Beautiful lady  Babys breath  Ladys veil  Bachelors buttons  Marys crown  Bleeding heart  Marys heart  Buttercup  Ladys locks  Carnation  Marys love of God  Chamomile  Ladys flower  Columbine  Our Ladys shoes  Dandelion  Marys bitter sorrow  Fern  Ladys hair  Forget-me-not  Eyes of Mary  Foxglove  Our Ladys gloves  Geranium  Lady beautiful  Honeysuckle  Ladys stick  Impatiens  Our Ladys earrings  Iris  Mary as Queen  Larkspur  Marys tears  Lily-of-the-valley  Our Ladys tears  Marigold  Marys gold  Morning glory  Our Ladys mantle  Ox-Eye daisy  Marys star  Pansy  Our Ladys delight  Petunia  Ladys praise  Rose  a symbol of Mary herself (she is known as the Mystical Rose)  Rosemary  Marys nosegay  Sweet pea  Our Ladys flower  Tulip  Marys prayer  Violet  Our Ladys modesty  Zinnia  Little Mary Find us on Instagram: @Asceticlifeofmotherhood and @PatristicNectarKids For more information on my blog to plant your own Mary garden: www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/marygarden-2025 If you want to see more PNP Kids Content, please consider making a donation! Visit https://patristicnectar.org/donations or text "PNP" to 53-555 to send a quick gift! #jesus #orthodoxchristianity #theotokos #virginmary #annunciation #feastoftheannunciation #feastdays #pnp #easternorthodoxy #spring #springgarden #springgardening #craftsforkids #homeschoolproject

title: Lent: Tips for Orthodox Families
description: Have you ever wanted to learn more about Lent and the different ways you can cultivate your own Lenten journey with your own family? Great Lent is a special gift that the Church gives us in order to help us re-focus our lives on Christ. The Church has set aside 40 days as a special time of repentance and calls us to a long and sustained spiritual effort. It is comparable to a school of repentance in which every Christian can go yearly in order to deepen their faith, re-evaluate, and, if possible, to change their lives. Its a wonderful journey to the very source of the Orthodox faith; a rediscovery of the Christian way of life. As we recognize this significant shift in our liturgical calendar, I wanted to provide resources and ideas to help you cultivate a lenten environment in your homes and with your families and share our favorite breakfast smoothie recipe! Berry Smoothie Makes 1 smoothie! Handful of spinach 1/2 banana 2 tbsp peanut butter 1 tbsp chia seeds 1 tbsp hemp hearts 1 tbsp flaxseed 3/4 cup frozen berries 3/4 cup water (or coconut water) Blend and serve immediately. title: Monastery Soup for the Feast of St Anthony the Great | PNP Kids
description: Monastery Soup for the Feast of St. Anthony the Great On January 17th, we celebrate St. Anthony the Great! Honor his feast day with this simple, hearty monastery-style soup, perfect for a cozy dinner paired with candlelight and crusty bread. Lighting a candle transforms an ordinary meal into a special celebration! While enjoying your meal, listen to the Life of St. Anthony on the Patristic Nectar App (find it under the synaxarion for the day). Afterward, spark a meaningful family discussion about what stood out in his inspiring life. Recipe: 3 tablespoons oil of choice 1 cup barley 1 carrot, finely grated 2 leeks, sliced 1 bay leaf 1/3 cup fresh parsley, minced Salt to taste 7 cups water or vegetable broth Directions: Heat the oil in a soup pot and toast the barley, stirring continuously for 1 minute. Add the carrot, leeks, bay leaf, parsley, salt, and 7 cups of water. Cook over low to medium heat, covered, for 4045 minutes, until the barley is tender. Add more water if needed. For extra flavor, add bouillon and mushrooms during the last 20 minutes of cooking. Remove the bay leaf and serve hot. Additional Resources: Listen to Life of St. Anthony on Patristic Nectar App: Patristic Nectar Synaxarion: https://app.patristicnectar.org/discover/synaxarion?date=2025-01-17 St. Anthony for Kids Blog Post: Ascetic Life of Motherhood Blog: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/stanthonythegreat Icon: Uncut Mountain Supply: https://www.uncutmountainsupply.com/icons/of-saints/by-name/a/st-anthony-the-great-20th-c-1an53/ Book - Life of St. Anthony by St. Athanasius: Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/Life-Anthony-Athanasius/dp/1631740318 Audiobook: Audible: https://www.audible.com/pd/Life-of-St-Anthony-of-Egypt-Audiobook/B07TS9HRK6?source_code=ASSORAP0511160006&share_location=pdp Celebrate the life of St. Anthony with this nourishing meal and a deeper connection to his story!

title: Vasilopita Tradition with Ascetic Life of Motherhood and PNP Kids
description: Let's make Vasilopita with whole wheat flower and honey! If you're unfamiliar with vasilopita, it's a special cake make on New Years to commemorate St Basil's feast day (Jan 1)! This tradition is said to be based on the story that follows: During a time of famine, the emperor demanded an excessive tax from the people of Caesarea, so each family had to give up all their valuables  money and/or jewelry. Upon finding out this injustice, St. Basil fearlessly defended his people, calling the emperor to repentance. The emperor was moved by St. Basils speech, canceled the tax and returned all the valuables to the Saint. The Saint was faced with a daunting task: out of a large amount of items, he had to return each one to its rightful owner. He prayed, then prepared a huge cake and baked the treasures inside of it. After calling his flock to prayer, he blessed and cut the cake, offering a piece to each person. Miraculously, each owner received his own valuables in his piece of the cake. Vasilopitas have been baked on St. Basils feast day every year since his repose, to commemorate this miracle. Recipe: Vasilopita with whole wheat flour and honey 6 eggs, in room temperature 2 sticks grass fed butter 1 cup honey 1 cup orange juice 2 cups whole wheat flour 1/2 cup almond flour 1.5 tbsp baking powder Zest of two orange Shredded coconut to decorate 1. Preheat your oven at 360F and butter a 10 inches round baking sheet 2. Separate the egg whites from the egg yolks 3. In a mixing bowl beat the egg whites until they form a soft meringue 4. In a separate mixing bowl beat well the egg yolks and butter to incorporate 5. Add the honey and continue to beat until it is well incorporated 6. Add the orange juice and zest and stir 7. Add the whole wheat flour, almond flour and baking powder and stir 8.Stir in *slowly* the meringue in 3 batches using a folding motion 9. Place the cake batter into the baking sheet 10. Bake for at least 45 min and then start checking with a knife or toothpick if it comes out clean. It might take up to 1 hour to bake fully. 11. When ready, let it cool down before you decorate with shredded coconut

title: The Parable of the Great Banquet
description: Father Joseph Thornburg Welcome to our special YouTube Kids edition of Father Jason's Sunday Gospel Homily! In this video, Father Jason will take your little ones on a spiritual journey, simplifying the Sunday gospel readings so that kids can better understand the Sunday Liturgy.  What to Expect: A warm and friendly introduction by Father Joseph. A simplified explanation of the Sunday gospel reading, making it relatable and engaging for kids. Thought-provoking questions to spark discussion and reflection. Inspiring messages to encourage your children's faith and love for Jesus. This video is perfect for children of all ages, whether they're new to the faith or have grown up in the Orthodox tradition. It's a wonderful way to introduce them to the beauty of the gospel and its teachings. title: Pascha, Fasting, and Saints | Kids Q&A with Priests
description: PNP Kids Questions: Ever wondered what kids want to ask their priest? Watch as our PNP Kids bring their most curious and heartfelt questions to Fr. Josiah and Fr. Jasonand get answers full of wisdom, love, and humor! Have a question for our priests? Wed love to hear from you! Submit your questions by sending a video to info@patristicnectar.org, and your submission might be featured in an upcoming episode. Dont forget to ask your own priest tootheres no question too small or big! Support PNP Kids Help us keep PNP Kids content free, engaging, and full of creativity by making a donation today and text PNP to 53-555. Thank you for supporting this ministry!

title: Celebrate St. Lucia Day: Learn, Bake Lussekatter, and Sing Along with Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: Join us on an exciting journey to learn about Saint Lucia of Syracuse, her inspiring life and martyrdom, and the beautiful traditions celebrated on her feast day. We'll also bake traditional lussekatter buns togetherperfect for observing this special occasion in a fun and meaningful way! Try the Recipe for Fast-Friendly Lussekatter (St. Lucia Buns): https://veganvvocals.com/2021/04/01/vegan-swedish-saffron-buns/ Sing Along with the Santa Lucia Song:  Lyrics: Night comes with heavy steps, Through our land, calling. Sunlight, the earth forgets; Shadows are falling. However dark the night, Rising with candles bright; Santa Lucia, Santa Lucia.  Audio: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1tVTNVEc0ikS_7QYNmccgdlRVuL3AjLeG/view Discover more about celebrating St. Lucia Day with the Ascetic Life of Motherhood's guide: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/stluciafeastdayguide?rq=lucia Celebrate the faith, traditions, and joy of Saint Lucia with us at PatristicNectarKids! Dont forget to like, share, and subscribe for more fun and educational Orthodox content.

title: Saint Nicholas, the Gold Coin Tradition, and Resources from Ascetic Life of Motherhood | PNP Kids
description: Celebrate St. Nicholas Day with Patristic Nectar Kids! Welcome to a joyful tradition of the Church! If youre new to celebrating St. Nicholas Day, Im thrilled to share this special feast with you. Its a meaningful and fun way to bring the life of the Church into your home and create lasting family memories. In the Orthodox Church, we honor saints on their feast days, and St. Nicholas' feast day is December 6th. A beloved tradition is leaving out shoes on the evening of December 5thdont forget to join in the fun! If youre new to celebrating feast days as a family, this is the perfect one to start with. Resources Mentioned in the Video: St. Nicholas Printable Tags: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/stnicholasday-ourfamily Saint Nicholas and the Nine Gold Coins Book: https://svspress.com/saint-nicholas-and-the-nine-gold-coins/ St. Nicholas Day Guide: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/stnicholasday-ourfamily Bring the joy of this beautiful feast into your home and discover the richness of Orthodox traditions with your little ones!

title: Koliva | Traditional Memorial Dish with Ascetic Life of Motherhood and PNP Kids
description: Koliva recipe 3 cups of uncooked wheat berries (bought mine from Amazon) 2 cups of finely chopped walnuts (or nut of choice) 1 cup golden raisins 1 cup pomegranate seeds 1 cup graham crackers (crushed) 1 tbsp ground cinnamon 1-1/2 cups powdered sugar (for topping) Jordan almonds for decoration Prepare wheat berries according to package directions. Usually have to boil for 40-60 mins and then cool. Once the wheat berries have boiled, drain and rinse and lay on a baking sheet to dry out using paper towels below and above. Once cooled, they will be ready to assemble. Mix all ingredients together, minus the powdered sugar. Put mixed items into a bowl and flatten the berries using your hand or parchment paper. Dust powdered sugar (generously) on top of the wheat berry mixture. Press down using parchment paper to flatten the powdered sugar and give it a more pristine finish. Then add the Jordan almonds in the shape of the cross on top of it and decorate as desired. Bring to church for the memorial and distribute to those in attendance. Pro tip: Dont add the powdered sugar decorations until just before the memorial as it tends to absorb any moisture, and can often shift in transport giving it an unfinished look. This creates about 7 cups of prepared wheat berries once boiled. The dish itself serves about 25. Wheat berries - https://amzn.to/409xD8d

title: Akutaq | A Traditional Alaskan Dessert for Saint Peter the Aleut on PNP Kids
description: Today for the feast of St Peter the Aleut, we are going to make a traditional Alaskan treat called Akutaq (pronounced a-goo-duck) which is a Yupik word that means mix them together. You may have heard it called Alaskan Ice Cream as well! This dish has been made with a variety of ingredients that would be plentiful in Alaska including animal fat from whatever animals were hunted like moose, caribou, fish, seal, whales. Then they would add sweet roots, and foraged berries. Mixed together it becomes a healthy tasty treat that would give them lots of strength and healthy nutrients! This would be a dish that St Peter the Aleut would likely have eaten as it was often sent with hunters on their long journey. So today lets learn how to make this traditional Alaskan dish using just a few simple ingredients! Ingredients: 1 cup lard (or Crisco) 1 cup sugar 2 cups of frozen berries (blueberries, salmon berries, cranberries, etc.) Wooden bowl Take the lard and add it to the bowl. Whip it up with your hand for at least three to five minutes until its creamy and fluffy. Pour at least a cup of sugar into the mixture (estimate). And whip it up until the sugar dissolves. Add the frozen berries to the mixture. And mix it up. Add more berries to the mixture if you want more. The akutaq should have a lot of berries in it. Now the akutaq is ready to eat! Will keep in the fridge for a few days!

title: Saint Phanourios | Patron Saint of Lost Things with Ascetic Life of Motherhood & PNP Kids
description: Have you ever heard of St. Phanourios, the patron saint of lost things? St Phanourios is known in the Orthodox Church as a saint who helps people find lost or stolen items. We ask St. Phanourios to help us find whatever we lost, and when we find it, we bake a cake and share it with friends and loved ones to give thanks. This special tradition comes from Greece and the special olive oil citrus cake is called Phanouropita! You can also bake this cake on his feast day, August 27th. In this episode, we are baking phanouropita donuts, which is ideal for sharing with others, an important element in the tradition! You can read more about this tradition and find the recipe on my blog: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/phanouropita-donuts Ingredients 1-1/4 cups vegetable oil (or substitute for oil of choice) 2-1/2 cups sugar 1-1/4 cups warm water Grated rind of 1 orange 1/2 cup orange juice (fresh orange juice is best) 1/2 tsp cinnamon 3 tsp baking powder 4 cups white flour 1/2 cup chopped walnuts (optional) 1/4 cup raisins (optional) Instructions Preheat your oven to 350 degrees. Sift flour, baking powder, and cinnamon together in a large bowl and set aside. Using a whisk, combine oil and sugar until blended. Add the warm water, orange rind, orange juice, and walnuts and mix well. Slowly add the flour mixture and combine until smooth. Add raisins and walnuts (if adding). Pour batter into well-greased donut pans. Bake at 350 degrees for 20 minutes or until the cake springs back when lightly touched. Cool on a wire rack. Top with powdered sugar.

title: What is the Dormition Fast? PNP Kids Presents - Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: In todays episode we are talking about the Dormition fast and how that might look in your family! Lets find some ways to pray together, fast, attend the Divine Services and give to those in need. The Dormition Fast is the final fasting season in the Liturgical year. It is one of the four fasting periods of the Orthodox Church year. The duration of the Dormition Fast is always August 1-14th, concluding on the Great Feast of the Dormition of the Theotokos (August 15th). As we recognize this significant shift in our liturgical calendar, I wanted to share some ways to embrace the Dormition Fast in your home! Dormition Blogpost with Additional Links: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/blog/dormitionguide-2024 Icons used: Uncut Mountain Supply (https://www.uncutmountainsupply.com/) Dormition Countdown Calendar: Draw Near Designs (https://www.drawneardesigns.com/calendars/dormition-countdown-calendar-diy-kit) Orthodox Childrens Calendar: Draw Near Designs (https://www.drawneardesigns.com/calendars/orthodoxchildrenscalendar) #patristicnectarkids #christianfamily #orthodoxy #orthodoxchurch #theotokos #dormition #sundayschool #christianhome #kidscontent #stayathomemom #sahm #catholic #orthodoxchurch #saints #homeschool #fasting

title: How We Celebrate Name Days with Ascetic Life of Motherhood on PNP Kids
description: How we celebrate name days in our family.  A name day is the feast day of your patron saint! Typically we are named after this saint, either at birth or when we join the church, so if you have a patron saint, your name day is the day your patron saint is celebrated!  If a service is offered, go to Church on your name day!  Display the icon of your saint in a prominent place.  Read the story of their life.  Host a name day party and invite friends.Focus on service - serve your guests or find a way to serve in the community.Eat your meals on a God Grant you many years plate.  Sing God Grant you many years and say a prayer to your saint! Name day gifts in our house are usually a new Orthodox book.  Take a picture each year with your icon and watch as you grow up with your Saint.How do you celebrate name days in your house?#patristicnectarkids #saints #nameday #feastday #orthodoxkids #orthodoxchurch #orthodoxsaints #happyfeast #sundayschool #homeschool #sahm #christianhome #orthodoxfamily #kidscontent

title: Cloud Slime Activity | Feast of the Ascension with PNP Kids
description: Join Ascetic Life of Motherhood in a cloud slime activity! The feast of the Ascension is celebrated 40 days after Pascha, so this year, we celebrate on June 13th! Cloud Slime Ingredients: 1 Cup of cornstarch 1/2 Cup of Inexpensive Conditioner Directions: Combine conditioner and cornstarch in a large mixing bowl and stir until dough forms. Finish kneading by hand until the dough is no longer sticky. We used 1/2 cup of conditioner and 1 cup of cornstarch, but you can make a bigger or smaller batch by adjusting the amounts. All you need to do is stick to a ratio of 2:1 or 2 parts cornstarch and 1 part conditioner. #patristicnectarkids #feastdays #orthodoxchristian #Orthodoxy #orthodoxfamily #christianfamily #christiantradition #kidsactivity #sundayschool #homeschool #familylife #kidscraft #slime

title: Saint Emilia | Plant a Fruit Bearing Tree with Ascetic Life of Motherhood & PNP Kids
description: Saint Emilia is a beautiful example of Christian motherhood. One can see the great virtue in her life, primarily through her childrenthe fruits of her labor and faith. As a mother, I find it inspiring that others are striving to raise Saints and, even more so, those who have succeeded at this monumental task!  It has been my desire to add fruit-bearing trees to our home each year, so I am using St Emilia as my inspiration, someone whose life produced so much good fruit. As we remember her each year, we can be re-inspired to produce good fruit through the spiritual effort in our lives. Of course, it takes YEARS to produce good fruit. So we must continue to tend to the garden, and when we fail, get up quickly and continue the task at hand.  As we add more fruit-bearing plants/trees to our property, we reclaim Eden, a glimmer of paradise. I hope to encourage parents to see their vocation as creating for themselves a little church and a slice of paradise in their own homes and in their children's hearts. Icon by @orthodoxdesignco (https://www.orthodoxdesigncompany.com/product-page/st-emilia) #patristicnectarkids #orthodoxhome #orthodoxfamily #homemaker #sahm #motherhood #christianhome #christianfamily #sundayschool #homeschool #orthodoxchristian #planting #fruitbearing #biblical #faith #prayer

title: Saints Constantine and Helen | Ascetic Life of Motherhood on PNP Kids
description: On May 21st, for the feast of St. Constantine and Helen, make homemade pesto for dinner with fresh basil! Its said that St Helen discovered the True Cross of Christ buried under basil (a symbol of victory)! In a food processor or blender, blend up: 2 cups basil leaves  cup pine nuts 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice 1 small garlic clove  teaspoon salt and black pepper to taste  cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for a smoother pesto  cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese Serve over chicken or with pasta! Monthly Liturgical Printables from Ascetic Life of Motherhood: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/store Grab some cute peg dolls: https://www.etsy.com/listing/1564357827/elevation-of-the-cross-peg-doll-set?ref=share_v4_lx Please remember to donate to Patristic Nectar to help our ministry grow and to see more content from it. To send a tax-deductible gift, text "PNP" to 53-555 from your device. #patristicenectarkids #asceticlifeofmotherhood #orthodoxy #orthodoxkids #orthodoxchurch #saints #christianfamilyvlogs #jesus #kidsyoutube #kidsrecipe #familyrecipe #familytraditions #christiantraditions #homecooking #feastdays #sahm

title: Lazarakia for Lazarus Saturday | Ascetic Life of Motherhood on PNP Kids
description: Lazarakia for Lazarus Saturday Jesus raised his friend Lazarus from the dead, and we commemorate this miracle and saint tomorrow on Lazarus Saturday. Your family can have a tangible way to participate in this feast by making this traditional bread.  Lazarus Saturday Printable from Ascetic Life of Motherhood: https://www.asceticlifeofmotherhood.com/store/lazarusbuns  Ingredients 6-1/3 cup (800g) of all-purpose flour 1-1/2 cups of lukewarm water 1 packet of yeast 3/4 cup of sugar 1 tsp of cinnamon 1/4 cup of olive oil 1/4 teaspoon of ground cloves (optional) 1/4 cup finely chopped walnuts (optional) 1/4 cup raisins (optional) whole cloves or chocolate chips to decorate the eyes  Instructions Mix the dry ingredients (including yeast) together and knead for 1 minute, then add oil and lukewarm water. Knead well until the batter becomes a nice soft dough. You can now add in nuts or raisins if using. Cover and let the dough rest for about 45 minutes in a warm place. Preheat the oven to 400F . Line two baking sheets with parchment paper. To shape each of the balls into small men, roll them out into an oblong shape, create a small ball to place as the head and press on top, and form two skinny strips and place them across the body in the shape of an x to represent arms. Insert 2 whole cloves or chocolate chips on the head to create the eyes. Should make 15-20 Lazarakia, depending on the size. Place the Lazarakia on the baking sheets. Bake for 20 minutes or until the bread rolls turn golden brown. Cool before serving. title: Veneration of the Precious and Life Giving Cross | Lenten Recipe with Ascetic Life of Motherhood.
description: The 3rd week of Great Lent with Ascetic Life of Motherhood! Recipe Crock Pot Lasagna Soup, serves 6 1 medium onion, diced 3 garlic cloves, minced 4  cups vegetable broth  cup dried brown lentils 1 teaspoon dried basil 1 teaspoon dried oregano 2 14 ounce can diced tomatoes 1 tbsp tomato paste 8 lasagna noodles, broken into pieces 3 cups chopped spinach leaves Optional: serve with vegan ricotta cheese (see below) Vegan Ricotta 1 1/2 cups raw cashews, soaked 1/2 cup water juice of 1 large lemon or 1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar 1  2 tablespoons nutritional yeast, optional 1 small garlic clove 1/2 teaspoon onion powder Directions: Place the onion, garlic, basil, oregano, lentils, broth, chopped tomatoes, and tomato paste into the slow cooker and stir a few times to blend. (optional: saute onion and garlic prior). Cover with lid and cook on high for 4 hours. 15 mins before serving, add the noodles and spinach to the slow cooker and give the mixture a stir. Allow the soup to continue cooking until noodles are tender and the spinach is wilted, about 15 minutes. Season the soup with salt and pepper to taste. optional top with vegan cashew ricotta (recipe below) Vegan Ricotta Directions: Soak cashews: let cashews sit in hot water for 5 minutes. Blend: Drain cashews and place all remaining ingredients into a blender or food processor, process until creamy stopping to scrape down the sides every few minutes. Taste for flavors adding any additional ingredients.

title: Easy Mucenici for 40 Martyrs of Sebaste | Ascetic Life of Motherhood
description: Easy Mucenici Ingredients: 1 Refrigerated Cinnamon rolls (large size) 1/2 cup walnuts (chopped) 1/2 cup honey (warmed) Directions: -Preheat oven to 350 F -Open cinnamon rolls. Unroll each cinnamon roll to a long roll, Cut each roll in half and create a ring by pinching the edges together. -Once you have the ring, twist it to form an 8 or infinity shape. -Place 2" apart on a prepared baking sheet. Bake for 12 mins. -Once out, let cool for 10 mins. -Heat the honey in a bowl for 1 min -Chop walnuts finely, and place in bowl -Once the buns have cooled, dip the top of the bun in honey, and then immediately dip in walnuts -Serve immediately and share with others! Can be stored in the fridge for up to a week. title: Ascetic Life of Motherhood | Homemade Butter Recipe for Saint Brigid
description: Introducing a brand new series on PNP Kids! Get ready to embark on a delicious journey into the heart of Orthodox Christian traditions! Our newest content contributor Khouria Destinie Winn is bringing the warmth of family feasts, time-honored recipes, and rich traditions right to your screens! From mouthwatering dishes to festive celebrations, join us as we explore the flavors that unite generations! INGREDIENTS 3 CUPS HEAVY WHIPPING CREAM 1 QUART ICE-COLD WATER SALT TO TASTE (OPTIONAL) EQUIPMENT -STAND MIXER WITH WHISK ATTACHMENT OR HAND-HELD MIXER -SPATULA -TOWEL OR SPLASH GUARD -MESH STRAINER (OPTIONAL) 1. Add the whisk attachment to your stand mixer. Add heavy cream to the mixing bowl. Start the mixer on the slowest setting, gradually raising the speed to the fastest setting. Keep a dish towel on hand to cover the bowl if the cream splashes out. 2. The cream will go through three stages: soft peaks, then stiff peaks, and finally the butter solids will separate from the buttermilk. Once you see the butter solids separate, stop the stand mixer and pour out the buttermilk. (The buttermilk can be reserved for other uses.) 3. Transfer the butter to a fine mesh sieve set over a large bowl. Using a spatula, press the butter into the sieve to remove any excess buttermilk. (The less buttermilk that remains in the butter, the longer the butter may last.) 4. Clean the stand mixer bowl, then return the butter to it. Add 1/4 cup of ice-cold water to the bowl then whip the butter again for around 10 seconds to wash the butter and get rid of any excess buttermilk. Once the water becomes cloudy pour it out and repeat the process until the water remains clear. 5 Pour out any water remaining in the bowl. Replace the whisk accessory with the flat beater. Add any ingredients you want to flavor the butter to the bowl and beat until they are just combined. Finished butter can be formed into a log or put into a small bowl. Store in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 2 weeks. Blessed Feast! Links | www.patristicnectar.org Donate | Text "PNP" to 53-555 to support our ministry! Follow | @PatristicNectarKids Kh. Destinie on Instagram @asceticlifeofmotherhood
